instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Low, ~1.3v.
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had extremely light liquid to the top edge of the board (near <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>), and had no green light. Had a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, which ended up being the SMC (awesome). Replaced SMC, and got rid of the short, and got a green light, but no fan. Proceeded to check my rails, and found <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> was only 1.28v. Hmmm. No obvious short on the line. Checked all caps on that rail and none appear to be shorted, and all look great. and replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> twice (with new/good chips), and no change. Cleaned the board well in the UC, and no change. All resistors along the circuit measure out well. The only other thing I can think of (and hope isn't the case) is a dead CPU/PCH, which is pulling down my vrtc line. Any way to confirm this? CPU/PCH does not get warm at all, of course.

I'd assumed vrtc is always present, but maybe something is missing prior to even <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> being pulled up? Thank you for any assistance in advance.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Low, ~1.3v.
threads.message: What is resistance to GND on PPVRTC? Usually <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> should get warm, check with your lip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Low, ~1.3v.
threads.message: Resistance to ground = 6.98Kohms; Diode = .386. It is getting ever so slightly warm, but definitely not much.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Low, ~1.3v.
threads.message: That should be well over 1M. Remove <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and all caps(4) on the line and if it doesn't go up your CPU is done. I have not much hope.....sorry.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Low, ~1.3v.
threads.message: Yeah, that's what I figured. I'll check on that and update the thread tomorrow--thanks, Dukefawks. I appreciate the quick responses and help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> Low, ~1.3v.
threads.message: Yep, dead CPU. Removed all associated caps and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, and RTG is still ~4-10kohm @ <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>. Working board measures ~1.23M. Thanks for helping me confirm! Not too many parts boards for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, so not a big loss.
